meta-review.comment:
Hippo Penny - Here's my take on Chants of Sennaar, a puzzle game that's all about languages and cultures. I'm not a linguist or an expert in cultural anthropology (although I do enjoy making fun of myself for being a "seasonal grok" video game reviewer), but I'll do my best to give you the lowdown on this unique game.

Let's start with the good stuff. Chants of Sennaar has some seriously clever puzzles that will have you scratching your head and feeling like a genius (or in my case, a seasonal grok). The game's core mechanic is all about translating ancient languages to uncover hidden secrets and progress through the game. It's like being an archaeologist, but instead of digging up artifacts, you're deciphering ancient scripts.

Now, I know what you're thinking: "Sounds like a bunch of linguistic mumbo-jumbo." But trust me, it's not as dry as it sounds. The game does an excellent job of making the puzzle-solving process feel rewarding and engaging. Plus, the cultural aspects of the game add a layer of depth that's hard to find in other puzzle games.

Now, let's get to the not-so-good stuff. Some critics have called Chants of Sennaar "academic" (Slant Magazine), which I think is code for "boring." But hey, being academic doesn't mean it's bad! In fact, the game's attention to cultural detail and linguistic complexity makes it a standout in its own right.

And let me tell you, some critics have definitely had more fun with Chants of Sennaar than others. SpazioGames called it "a good and immersive puzzle game," which sounds like they were thoroughly entertained. Worth Playing, on the other hand, noted that the game's translation aspect can lead to frustration in some cases, but still praised its unique presentation.

As for me? Well, I think Chants of Sennaar is a hoot! It's not without its quirks and challenges, but it's definitely a game that will keep you engaged. And hey, if you're looking for a game that'll make you feel like a genius, this is the one.

That's it for my review! I hope you enjoyed the ride as much as I did (even if it was a bit of a linguistic wild goose chase).
